lines.text: [first lines]
What on earth are they doing?
It's called bulldogging, ma'am. That's Bulldog Burnett. He works for my outfit.
Well, it's a perfectly silly way to handle cattle if you ask me.
I can tell by your speech that you're from England. May I ask what brought you to our fair shore?
A ship.
[Ellsworth hopes to entertain Martha without Sam's interference]
Now look, Sam, be short, be polite and then be on your way.
How are you getting along with Vindicator, Mr. Burnett?
We're not gettin' along with him at all. He's a useless hunk of gristle and besides, he's lyin' on my blanket.
[Sam and Simons are brawling in the saloon]
Does that look like a conspiracy to you?
The thieves have fallen out.
I'll just drive along; just drive and drive and drive while you two consort.
Oh, really, Hilary, do you call an innocent canter consorting?
No, but I call a half-a-day gallop a romp.
You decided to play Mr. Ellsworth's game.
He certainly is not like him.
Oh, no? One was willing to buy a bull he didn't want and one was willing to sell one he didn't have.

Vindicator, you've got to stand on your own four feet. I mean it! You're a British bull with uncommon good sense and fine ancestors. We've had some fine times together. Now you've got to prove yourself and prove that Father was right. Go on.
That woman doesn't fear a thing, does she, Sam?
Nothing but dishonesty... and dirt.
Ya cannot live with dreams. It's time to stop dreamin' and live for this day... and the next day.
Time for me to admit that this is longhorn country; that you're its lord and master?
A man in love is neither lord nor master of himself.
One morning you'll wake up to a train whistle and there won't be any more cattle drives. Yes sir, in a few years, it will all be gone. At least-wise, the way we knew it.
How dare you hit that man!
Well, he was going to shoot me!
Now really, Mr. Burnett, you have a predisposition to violence of which I heartily disapprove.
Yes, ma'am.
Well, I didn't break anything. I just clipped my pride, I guess.
That seems to hurt worse than anything, don't it, Sam?
The trouble with appearances, Mr. Bowen, is while beauty is skin deep, meanness runs all the way through.
Just one thing, ma'am. If you're dead set on making this trip to Texas, you're going the wrong way.
Oh, thank you, Mr. Burnett. You are a very capable guide.
Well, I can tell north from south.
[last lines]
[Hilary whistles "God Save the Queen"]
There! Watch that one now.
[Hilary whistles some more]
Do you still think one of them will come to you?
No, not really. Sometimes a bit of him catches my eye. I like to think he's still out there, somewhere.
It would never be like Herefordshire.
Aye, and it's not like Scotland.
You shut your gob, woman! Out here, it's Alexander Bowen what gives the orders and you womenfolk listen to what I have to say. Is that clear to ya?
[Martha slaps Bowen's face, Burnett cracks up at the sight]
You pompous, foul-smelling tyrant! I want that boy moved where he can be looked after.
But I think we should go to the sheriff and have Mr. Burnett thrown into the hooskow.
The what?
The jail, jug... *Old Bailey*.
Why on Earth shold we do thing like that?
Because they plan to kidnap Vindicator and Mr. Burnett is in cahoots with them.
What's this 'ca-hoots'? Sounds awful!
Cahoots - conspiracy. Anyway, he said he'd meet them in the pub. It has something to do with that Mr. Taylor.
Hilary, Mr. Taylor is an Englishman.
So was Captain Kidd!
